question: What do you mean by hymnifying the second half or fractal-like duck form?
answer: hymnifying the second half' is what i sometimes call the thing in a traditional song form where the 4th 8th is the 5 chord, and the 8th 8th is the 1 chord, and the 7th 8th usually contains 1 over 5 and 5. you've heard it thousands of times. she'll be coming around the mountain, etc. Fractal like duck form is a phenomenon that occurs where the landing point of the first half is in the same relative time position as the landing point of the whole thing, relative to the whole thing. so for example, over the course of a 4 bar phrase of lyrics, let's say your first line lands halfway through the second bar, that's squarely on the 4th quarter of the first half. then your next line should have its landing point at the top of the 4th bar, which is the halfway point of the second half, and hence the start of the 4th quarter of the whole thing. so your landing point of the entire thing is in the same position relative to the whole as the landing poing of the first half was to the first half. this creates a fractal-like self-similarity that the mind responds very well to, and is present in many many lyrics/songs and rhythmic poems.

question: Hi, just wondering what's up with the new vid?I know (as always) you are working as hard and fast and as you can, and I'm sure the song and video will be awesome.. But, I'm wondering if there's something you're stuck on, or if you hit a particular obstacle or something like that? Sorry, don't mean to be rude or to ask one of those WHAT'S TAKING SO LONG!?!? questions... I just hope everything's going smoothly?
answer: all things considered, i really haven't done that many full length songs with videos. actually, all things considered, i really haven't even done that many full length songs in audio either. i have done several, but still not that many. in many ways i am still refining my techniques. there are other things that distracted me as well. the first week after movie star was released, i did several reality clips, because i was intending to release them daily, so i had to catch up on about 9 clips. that took about a week. then i had a lot of trouble really figuring out what direction to go next. i have a strong desire to do only songs (with videos) forever. but free videos (non-song videos) are important too. i ultimately decided to stick with songs. then came the next challenge, which is a demon i've been battling forever regarding song selection. how the hell do i choose what song to do? and do i use randomization or not? this issue has been destroying me for many years, and i can never get my head around it. it seems like every song is good because there is something bad about it. it's like movies -- every story is good because there is something bad about it -- it gives the characters something to overcome. there's so many different types of songs that are each a different way for a different reason, and the only thing that makes sense is to do them ALL. i've gotten very experimental with songwriting, and written a lot of weird shit. i've also had the desire to write much much more 'normal' sounding stuff. i have a lot of both. Any individual choice for what the next song is always feels totally wrong. like, oh no i can't do that one, it's too weird. or, oh no that one's too normal. or, oh no, that one's too this, or too that. The bottom line is, every song is a certain way, and it's like people, every person has a unique way that they are, and every single person is unlikeable in some way, but that's what makes them likeable. picking just one song has always been completely impossible, and every time i have to just give up and use brute force randomization. which means i just put all the choices in a huge list (usually hundreds long) and use the computer to pick a random number and do that one. this can be good, but also scary, and it really picks songs that sometimes maybe i shouldn't have done. crazy/raining was picked this way, and i just don't think i would have picked such a lonely/mopey ballad if i had had my own choice. free to was picked this way, and i guess it was an ok choice. california was picked this way, and it is a fun song, but for fucks' sake if i was choosing it manually, why would i pick another weed song? i've already referenced 'getting high' enough. people are gonna think i'm obsessed with weed now. cuz i love you, again, another choice that i never would have made manually, and i was scared to do it after it was picked, but luckily i was able to completely re-write the verses to make it work. movie star and got to know what's going on were also random choices, but i felt more comfortable with those, especially because they were only 10% written, so i got to finish the writing in whatever way i was comfortable with in the current time. but there are just so many songs in that list that are just so not the right ones to do yet. i really really want to do them all, but it is always impossible to choose one. But it seems that if i actually can make the right choice then it seems i will increase my chances of getting a good final product that i think is really strong and great, and right for the time. so this time i took another shot at it. i started going through the list, and making note of certain ones that i thought should be 'in the running' for selection ... and i started creating like a ranking list, as i was going through, i was keeping track of which one was my first choice, second choice, etc etc. it took me a long time to work through the list, and i didn't even finish the list before i realized, again, as always, that this is never going to work. i realized i was ignoring songs that are barely written, for some reason. and i was excluding ones that i was nervous about, but actually would be great choices if i could just follow through without questioning. so i think after several days on this system, i somehow got the idea for a hybrid system, where i just go through the list, and tab any ones that i definitely do NOT want picked right now, to the side. this was actually very quick. i actually excluded more than i thought, which was a little risky because it was very similar to the previous all-manual system, but i got through very quickly, and out of the list of 400 i got it down to about 41. my plan was to then make a random pick out of those 41. but i was really nervous about it, and i knew if i got a pick that i hated i would hate the whole system again and be lost again. so i actually went through those 41 again, and really took out ones that i just thought weren't right. and i got it down to 27. THEN i finally made the random selection, out of those 27. the song that came up was just fine, and a good pick. but i think it would have not been picked in manual mode, because it was barely written (just like a one word chorus/hook) and i don't think it would have made the rankings as a 'favorite' because i couldn't really have any strong feelings about it yet, because the majority of the 'meat' had not yet been written. but thanks to the random/hybrid system, it never got excluded from the legit candidates list, because i do think it is a perfectly strong hook and there was nothing wrong with it, and it can easily be written into something great. so i believe that was wednesday aug, 23 that the pick was made. The next issue is just the issue of schedule, and time, and productivity. I have been desperately been trying to find ways to increase production speed by, well, i dunno, 1000%? for many years now. it has been an ongoing problem that what i do takes so much longer than i want it to. so i made a bold goal in saying that i need to have these song+videos done in 2 weeks, and release them every other tuesday. during june of this year i was roughly able to stay afloat on a 1-week per song schedule, that was with the audio only. however, doing a video for a full length song, while i haven't done that many, it has always taken somewhere around 4 weeks or more, just for the video. that was true of crazy/raining, free to, movie star, etc. And this particular song is longer than all of those, it's 3:29. so really, 2-weeks for both audio and video is outlandish. But i keep holding on to the idea that there are always more undiscovered ways of doing graphics that are drastically faster, and still interesting. it's a goal i've been chasing for many years, and i can never seem to reach it, but i still keep believing it's possible. because i've just got so much material left to do, it just needs to happen drastically faster than it is. one key thing i keep coming back to is how i started making videos in the first place. originally i had no idea how to do it, and i thought video making in general was way over my head, but i knew that there always has to be a way to express myself even just using the most simple tools and techniques. and if you look at the first few videos i was doing, throughout 2013 and early 2014, it is clear that i barely knew anything except how to put words on the screen at the right time. but the point is, i knew that you can always express yourself just fine no matter how limited your tools are. so that is my main beacon of light nowadays in terms of trying to drastically reduce production time -- i always keep coming back to this idea that it must be possible to still have a good fun time in videos, with 90% less work than i've been doing. it's a goal that i just can't and won't let go of. So anyway, the pipedream for this project was 2 weeks for the whole damn thing, writing, audio, video. that would put the release date to tues, sep 5. so i got straight to writing, the writing was done in about 3 days, and i think it came out great. very glad, and very happy with the choice. so i put down extremely temp audio, with the right timing and tempo, and jumped into the video. tried to move as fast as i could, although really i was only putting down sort of a very basic layer of what happens, and knew that i really needed to go back through and spice everything up (i did this with movie star). approaching friday before the tuesday deadline, i was basically only about 50% through the video, on the most absolute basic level, so that means there was still a huge amount of work to do. but i knew i needed to get to the audio, especially because there is a delay on that, if i want it to get to itunes/spotify in time for the release, it actually needs to be done and sent 2 days in advance. so i went to the audio .... but then, more demons. i just felt really stuck in a rut, like i've been using the same sounds forever, and i've been wrestling with these instrument randomization methods which work really really well but there's always flaws in the system. i first started using this type of method in 2015 or so-- the basic idea is you randomly select a sound from all your sounds, just pick it entirely randomly, and then you get to decide where in the song it fits. so even if you pick something totally stupid that you think you can never use, if you search through the song, verse, chorus, all the parts of the song, you can always find a certain place that it works. and the result is, when you are listening to the song, you hear these things that are really fresh, and they all sound like the right sound for that point in time. but you never had to go through any effort searching for a sound that would fit. instead, you randomly picked the sound, and searched for where it fit. this was a huge breakthrough i had in early 2015, and i've used this random system for any long song i've done ever since. it works great and produces really interesting results very quickly and effortlessly, and it seems like it eliminates the need to worry or even think. you just keep doing instrument picks, and dropping them into where you think they go, and just keep going, instrument after instrument, until eventually the song is full. But unfortunately, this system starts to fail, sort of like an exponential curve, as the song gets about 75% full, you start running out of places to put things, and yet some of the main important pieces will remain still un-picked. like real basic stuff, like the HH for the verse. or the bass for the chorus. so the question is always, when is it time to abandon the random system and just use normal judgement, pick an ordinary bass sound, and just play the part. But for some reason i have real serious problems just using 'ordinary judgement.' especially on long songs. i just can't seem to do it, i'm so burned out on decision making, and i'm also so scared to make 'ordinary choices', and i'm just so aware that i need to keep things very fresh. and yet, another part of me wants to think only from a writers perspective, and life seems so much simpler when i'm just writing and not thinking about instruments. makes me wish i was just a solo acoustic guitar player/singer where all i have to do is just play the song and not worry about what it's made of, texturally. seems like writing the song is the main game i'm interested in here, and it is so draining to have to worry about the textures on top of that. seems counter-productive, almost like each skill is working to make up for flaws in the other, and when you have to care about both it kind of ruins the game. but, once i get into a good system, it can be really good and fun and can get great results, but what i'm saying is, over the last few years i've been kind of walking on eggshells trying to figure out how to balance the random and non. i keep desperately trying to find solid procedures, to avoid this lost feeling of having no idea what to do next. And i also figured it is really time for me to go out and find some new sounds, which is something i always say i'm gonna do but never do. so i cruised some sites and got a bunch of stuff, and also spent some money, and so basically i spent a whole day cruising for new sounds. this was saturday, sep 2. pretty clear that sep 5 is impossible at this point, but i was making progress on getting some new sounds, and i figured it would be useful. So the next question is, what the heck kind of randomization system am i using, how do i balance it with more 'reasonable' and simple choices, and how do i keep my head straight, and have a real solid procedure for this. i seemed really stuck again, but i very quickly had another huge breakthrough. i decided to pick 50 sounds, manually, and just keep it to those 50 only. this is way less than i usually would need if i was doing random picks, but when i'm doing random picks, as soon as it gets above 100, the computer starts flaking out and can't deal with it. and it's not efficient, because i would be picking like a percussion sound, which might be a whole percussion kit, and i would be only using a tiny shaker or tamborine in like 1 spot, and then picking another instrument entirely. so it's very wasteful, RAM wise, if you think about it. so i just decided i would pick 50 only, and for some reason i decided to pick manually. because i think i tried the same approach once before randomly, and i was stuck without any bass sounds, or something weird like that. so i picked them manually and made sure to spread it out so i had enough of each type. enough drum kits, enough basses, enough 'keyboard' type sounds, enough stringed type sounds, enough lead sounds, enough weird ?? sounds, etc, tried to keep it balanced. and chose mainly from the list of stuff i've made myself over the years, stuff which i've saved that i really like. including a lot of crazy sounds i made while working on history of the entire world. and i got all the choices in order from 1 to 50 so i could easily make random picks. and i just started doing it, picking a random number, and finding where the heck it goes. I also had the song broken up into sections, so each pick was actually an instrument and a section. so this helped ensure that i wasn't neglecting certain sections. i randomized long lists in advance, so i just checked the list to see what the numbers were. so 41, 10 means i have to take instrument 41, and go to section 10, and find a place for it. and pow, very very quickly the song got up to critical mass, and a lot of really special things were going into the song. Within just a couple days, it was about 75% full, with still many crucial things missing (kick or some sections, HH/perc missing for some parts, bass missing for some parts, chords missing for certain parts, etc etc) but generally it seemed the majority of the song was filled in. this was probably about mid-week, just after tues sep 5, so the initial (impossible) deadline had already failed, but i was still aiming for the following tuesday. again, a challenge presented itself as to how to know when to get off the random system, and when to just start finishing and making my own decisions and just filling in the essentials that are still missing. but i've just been so drained and in-a-rut about these issues that i was really careful about this and wanted to know what the solid procedure is. ultimately, what i've learned from this, is i've decided that it should be about 100 random picks per minute of song, because it was at about 350 picks that i really became sure that the random picking had saturated the song as much as it could, and some of the 'weirder' sounds had already come up so many times that any more would make them not sound unique anymore. so i think in the future, the idea is to let it get to 100 picks per minute of song (i.e. for a 3 minute song, the limit should be 300 picks) and then just jump to car-testing, troubleshooting. it's always good to ditch into troubleshooting early, even if you know it's terribly incomplete. i went to car testing extremely early on the 'movie star' song, just for the hell of it, because that one was actually on a week deadline, and while there were huge things missing, you just put the biggest issues into a list, then fix the list, then do it again. and believe it or not, i think it's never been more than 4 lists to completion, even when i ditch into car testing a bit early. so anyway, i went to troubleshooting, really planning to get it set by sunday morning, to have it sent out by then, and type in a deadline of tues (which means it's out of my hands and the stores would publish it on tues) and just create an outrageous externally imposed deadline to finish the video, which by the way still required a huge amount of work. but i just still wasn't done troubleshooting until later sunday/monday, and i just keep being more meticulous with this thing. because i just want it to be really good! so the mix was declared done on monday or so, but i still didn't want to send it until i was a little more sure that i could definitely finish the video within 2 days. Then, something else happened, i heard back from youtube about the content ID system, which is something that i've sought after for a long, long, time, which is the ability to monetize re-uploads of my videos on other peoples' channels. this is a very exclusive tool set that big youtube creators and companies have access too, which allows them to claim other peoples' videos when they infringe their copyrights, and either have them taken down, or, more often, just leave them up and have them monetized on that user's channel. this could be a big potential source of income, and for me, since i absolutely never put ads on my own channel, and i've always been slightly uncomfortable with people uploading censored verions, remixes, etc, (but still never wanted to police it or take it down cuz that's just mean) it would be a great way for me to actually earn some income without having to monetize on my own channel, if i just monetize all that stuff whenever other people re-upload it. it could mean the ability to actually really do this 100% full time, without having to work for anyone else, ever. and also maybe afford to move to a better studio, start actually playing drums in videos, get a faster computer, etc.. so i've been patiently trying to get access to this feature, but it's very very exclusive, and it's very hard to get it, and youtube has told me in the past that they weren't going to let me have it. but i recently heard back from someone who seems to be guiding me through the proper steps, so there's all these certifications i had to take, so THAT kept me occupied for a day or 2, then i finally got back to working on the video. and at this point, i've blown past multiple tuesdays since the original tuesday i had fantasized (however impossibly) about having it done, and i just ... again, i'm still desperate to have a breakthrough that makes this stuff 10 times faster and easier, and i am holding on to the hope that i can do that. and in the future i still think i can get it down to 2 weeks, for song+video. additionally, just in the last week or so i have started to think maybe i should still alternate between songs and non-songs. with either one hopefully being done in 2 weeks. anyway, so that is what's going on, and to be honest right now the video process is going very slowly. looking to have a similar breakthrough that i had the other week with the music, something that allows me to just blast through on simple-mode, and would allow me to easily keep things interesting, over the course of a 3 and a half minute song. i mean, what i do is not exactly run-of-the-mill. the reason i've acheived such great results is because i kind of have a standard of making things as good as i possibly can. if i had just not cared, i don't think i would be where i am today, and gotten the results i've gotten. not to mention, making full videos for 3-minute-plus songs is something that i have still only done a relatively low number of times, and in addition, i always need to make sure that i am pushing things to new heights and challenging peoples' expectations, which again is one of the staple elements that has brought me to where i am today. so yes i am desperately looking for ways to make things 10 times faster, but also while preserving the ability to make each moment, and the whole product, mind-meltingly special, if i possibly can.
